title: Declan Carr
text:
Declan Carr (born 30 July 1965) is an Irish retired <a href="hurling">hurler</a> who played as a midfielder for the <a href="Tipperary%20GAA">Tipperary</a> senior team.
Carr joined the team during the <a href="National%20Hurling%20League%201988-89">1988-89 National League</a> and was a regular member of the starting fifteen until he quit the panel after the <a href="National%20Hurling%20League%201993-94">1993-94 National League</a>. He made a brief return for the <a href="All-Ireland%20Senior%20Hurling%20Championship%201999">1999 championship</a>. During that time he won two <a href="All-Ireland%20Senior%20Hurling%20Championship">All-Ireland</a> medals, three <a href="Munster%20Senior%20Hurling%20Championship">Munster</a> medals, one <a href="National%20Hurling%20League">National League</a> medal and one <a href="GAA%20All%20Stars%20Awards">All-Star</a> award. Carr captained the team to the All-Ireland title in 1991.
At club level Carr is a one-time <a href="Tipperary%20Senior%20Club%20Hurling%20Championship">county club championship</a> medalist with <a href="Holycross-Ballycahill%20GAA">Holycross-Ballycahill</a>.
He has also managed the Holycross-Ballycahill senior team and the Tipperary U-21 team.
Early life.
Declan Carr was born in <a href="Dublin">Dublin</a> in 1965. He was educated locally and in 1980 he moved to <a href="Ballycahill">Ballycahill</a> in <a href="County%20Tipperary">County Tipperary</a>. While Carr went on to play <a href="hurling">hurling</a> for <a href="Tipperary%20GAA">Tipperary</a>, his brother, <a href="Tommy%20Carr%20%28Gaelic%20footballer%29">Tommy Carr</a>, later played <a href="Gaelic%20football">football</a> for <a href="Dublin%20GAA">Dublin</a>.
Playing career.
Club.
Carr played his club <a href="hurling">hurling</a> with <a href="Holycross-Ballycahill%20GAA">Holycross-Ballycahill</a>. He won a senior <a href="Tipperary%20Senior%20Hurling%20Championship">county championship</a> with the club in 1990.
Inter-county.
Carr’s <a href="hurling">hurling</a> skills were quickly spotted by the inter-county selectors and he soon joined the <a href="Tipperary%20GAA">Tipperary</a> under-21 team in the mid-1980s. From here he moved onto the senior panel, playing in the <a href="National%20Hurling%20League">National Hurling League</a> campaign of 1988-1989. That year he made his senior championship debut before later collecting his first <a href="All-Ireland%20Senior%20Hurling%20Championship">All-Ireland</a> medal following a <a href="1989%20All-Ireland%20Senior%20Hurling%20Championship%20Final">final</a> win over <a href="Antrim%20GAA">Antrim</a>. At the end of the year Carr was presented with an <a href="GAA%20All%20Stars%20Awards">All-Star</a> award.
Two years later in 1991 Carr was appointed captain of the Tipperary team.
That year he won his first <a href="Munster%20Senior%20Hurling%20Championship">Munster</a> medal as a full member of the Tipperary team, before later winning his second All-Ireland medal following a win over <a href="Kilkenny%20GAA">Kilkenny</a>.
In 1994 Carr decided to leave Ireland, moving to the United States, before returning again in 1998. He regained his place on the Tipperary team, winning a <a href="National%20Hurling%20League">National Hurling League</a> medal in 1999. He retired from inter-county hurling panel in 1999.
Coaching career.
In January 2021, Carr was appointed manager of the <a href="Tipperary%20GAA">Tipperary</a> ladies football team.
